section.title: Introduction
section.p: The pipeline engine API allows embedding the execution of pipelines in your Java applications, whether server-side or client-side.

section.title: API
section.p: The reference example using those APIs is the command-line application found under OPS.java. The steps required to execute a pipeline are detailed below. Please also refer to the source code of OPS.java.

section.title: Parse the command-line arguments
section.p: Please refer to the source code for more details.

section.title: Initialize a resource manager
section.p: Pipelines usually access resources (or files) through an abstraction layer composed of one or more resource managers. The code below initializes a Priority Resource Manager, which attempts to load resources first from the filesystem, then from the classloader. The reason for using the classloader is that the Orbeon JAR file contain bundled configuration resources that must be accessible.
In this particular case, if the -r command-line argument is present, a sandbox directory path is passed to the Filesystem resource manager upon instanciation.

section.title: Initialize OPS Properties
section.p: This initializes the OPS properties with the default properties file bundled in the Orbeon JAR file.

section.title: Build a processor definition object
section.p: This step builds a ProcessorDefinition object containing the name of the processor to run (here the oxf:pipeline processor), as well as the URL to bind to the config input of that processor. The mapping of processor names to classes is done in processors.xml, a resource bundled in the Orbeon JAR file.

section.title: Initialize a PipelineContext
section.p: The PipelineContext represents a context object passed to all the processors running in a given pipeline session. In general, you just need to create an instance.

section.title: Run the pipeline
section.p: This is where all the real work is done. A PipelineEngineFactory instanciates a PipelineEngine object, which then runs the pipeline. This method is provided with the ProcessorDefinition and the PipelineContext created earlier, as well as an ExternalContext instance providing input and output access to the pipeline.

section.title: Display exceptions if needed
section.p: If an exception is caught, information about the error is displayed.
